Executive Summary
 
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility: 

It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations. STS Intermodal is committed to operating the facility in a manner that minimizes or eliminates accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. Safe work practices, training of our personnel, and implementation of spill prevention measures are utilized at STS.  STS has also implemented a Hazardous Materials Contingency Plan and Emergency Procedures (HMCPEP) which includes notification of the local fire authority and implementation of hazardous materials cleanup by an outside contractor so that appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to control accidental releases if and when they occur.

This document has been prepared in accordance with the EPAs Risk Management Plan regulation (40 CFR, Part 68). The substances and processes considered during the preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria established in the rules.

Your facility and the regulated substances handled:

The facility is located at 3601 NW Marine Drive, Troutdale, Oregon (see Figure 1 - Site Location Map).  The facility is located in Multnomah County, in Section 22 of Township 1 North, Range 3 East, on Tax Lots 400 and 500.  STS leases the property (approximately 6 acres) from Parenti Properties LLC.  The site is situated in an area zoned for General Industrial (GI).  It is bounded to the north by Salmon Creek and vacant fields, to the east by vegetation and Swift Transportation, to the south by vegetation, Arata Creek and G&R Auto Wreckers, and to the west by a truck yard.

The 6-acre subject facility includes 9,120 square feet of covered industrial and office space.  The site contains one main structure with an attached covered storage on the north exterior and a separate covered storage structure further to the northeast. Remaining areas of t

he site consist of paved surfaces, graveled areas and landscaped areas in select locations and surrounding the perimeter.  Numerous bulk storage tankers, both loaded and empty, are stored in the western and northern portions of the site.  STS stores and transports 20-foot long stainless steel fully enclosed chemical storage tanks onsite (referenced as ISO-tanks).  Hazardous materials are stored indoors, outdoors under cover, and in exposed outdoor areas.  STS does not generate hazardous waste onsite. 

STS Intermodal has three regulated substances which require RMP regulation.  These were all under the toxics classification.  There were no flammables identified at the facility.  
¿	Ammonia Hydroxide (29% Ammonia) - Isotanks have 35,567 pounds of solution per container and there can be up to 9 containers onsite at one time.
¿	Epichlorohydrin - Isotanks have 44,093 pounds per container and there can be up to 2 containers onsite at one time.
¿	Vinyl Acetate - Isotanks have 40,404 pounds per container and there can be up to 2 containers onsite at one time.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:

STS and its emergency response contractor are responsible for providing initial response for the spill or release of hazardous materials at the facility. STS has a designated Primary Emergency Coordinator (EC) and an alternate in the event of an emergency.  Depending on the scope and scale of the spill, STS may engage the services of a spill response contractor.
The EC has the authority to commit the necessary corporate resources, including services and equipment, to control the spill or release. In addition, the EC has access to reference material and facility Safety Data Sheets (SDS).  In the event of an emergency involving outside response agencies, the EC's primary responsibility is to contact emergency responders, provide support in the form of information regarding the materials or facilities involved, and to ac

cess STS's resources as needed.

The five-year accident history:
STS Intermodal has had no accidental spills or releases of regulated hazardous material in the last 5 years.

The emergency response program:

The facility maintains a Hazardous Materials Contingency Plan and Emergency Procedures that contains specific procedures for employees to take in the event of an emergency or accidental release. This information also contains the names and numbers of responding outside agencies. Emergency actions and response for toxic releases have been coordinated with Gresham Fire & Emergency Services, City of Troutdale Police Department, and Clean Harbors a hazardous materials cleanup response provider. Annual drills are held in order to review these activities with the responsible responding units.

Planned changes to improve safety:

STS hired Creekside Environmental Consulting, LLC to complete an independent audit of its operations last year and is committed to implementing recommendations that minimize or eliminate onsite releases of regulated hazardous materials.
